Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Spatial Control of Condensate and Wetting Regimes using Heterogeneous and Hierarchical Surface Structures for Enhanced Heat Transfer

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1511453
PI: McCarthy, Matthew

The goals of this project are to develop heterogeneous surface structures and investigate effects of spatially varying surface wettability and thermal conductivity on wetting and heat transfer rates during condensation. The project seeks to improve heat transfer rates by maintaining precise control of the liquid-vapor interfaces and segregating wetted and non-wetted regions on engineered surfaces. Thus, results of the project could improve the design of heat transfer systems and increase energy efficiency for a variety of applications, including electronics cooling, desalination and water purification, and chemical processing. The project will involve graduate and undergraduate students, and outreach activities are planned to engage local students, especially those from under-represented groups.

The project will combine bio-templated nanofabrication techniques and initiated chemical vapor deposition (iCVD) to create heterogeneous surfaces with patterned variations in wettability and thermal conductivity. The bio-templating process uses self-assembly and metallization of the Tobacco mosaic virus to create a uniform layer of high surface area nanostructures. iCVD is used to coat the nanostructured surfaces with thin layers of low surface energy polymeric materials. The combination of mixed wettability and mixed conductivity will provide spatial control over condensate droplets to enhance heat transfer. The investigators will use confocal scanning laser microscopy and high-speed imaging during condensation and condensate removal to characterize the performance of surfaces and the effects of heterogeneous architectures. Results could guide practitioners in improving condensation heat transfer rates by enabling precise control over condensate dynamics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Phase-change heat transfer plays a critical role in power generation, chemical processing, water purification, HVAC, and many more industries. As such, even modest enhancements of phase-change heat transfer processes will translate directly to substantial energy and cost savings on a large scale. The realization of next-generation technologies to enhance phase-change heat transfer is of critical importance due to its impact on energy, environmental, and water resources as well as high-heat-flux cooling applications. This project leveraged multiscale fabrication techniques (from nano-templates to traditional machining) to conduct a fundamental study of wetting dynamics, condensate removal, and heat transfer on multiscale heterogeneous surface architectures. Nano-coatings based on the self-assembly of the Tobacco mosaic virus (TMV) were combined with initiated chemical vapor deposition (iCVD) of conformal defect-free polymer films to create surfaces with spatial control of condensate and wetting states. A systematic investigation of the complex physical phenomena occurring during condensation on heterogeneous surface structures was undertaken. The insights gained during this fundamental study led to the realization of novel multiscale architectures combining mixed wettability (local variations in surface energy), mixed conductivity (local variations in thermal conductivity), and hierarchical designs optimized for enhanced condensation heat transfer. This work culminated in the creation of robust and scalable surfaces manufactured using cheap and readily available techniques. These ?amphiphilic surfaces? were shown to reject condensate for low thermal resistance during condensation.
